The Language File¶

The language.json file is a JSON file that provides a JSON object with information about a language and its spellchecking data.

Presets¶

The language.json of a language may define a set of presents, named groups of modules. When you use the build tool to generate Hunspell files, instead of specifying your own group of desired modules on the command line, you may specify the name of a preset instead to build the modules of the preset into Hunspell files.

The main JSON object of language.json may contain a presets key with another object as value.

{
    "presets": {}
}

Each key in the presets object is the name of a preset, the name that you can pass to the build tool if you want to generate the Hunspell files for the modules of that preset. The key points to an object that holds all the information about the preset.

{
    "preset1": {},
    "preset2": {},
    "presetN": {}
}

The object of a preset may contain any of the following fields:

default:

Whether the preset is the default preset (true) or not (false). You should only define this key in one preset object, with value true. There is no need to use the key on any other preset object.

Default value: false
displayName:

Optional display name of the preset.

This field should be written using the language of the folder where languages.json is stored.
description:

Optional description of the preset.

This field should be written using the language of the folder where languages.json is stored.
aff:

List of modules of word-formation rules to load.
dic:

List of modules of word lists to load.
rep:

List of modules of word replacement suggestion rules to load.

Lists of modules may be specified in two different ways. If you only need to specify a list of modules to include, you can provide that list directly:

{
    "aff": ["module1", "module2/module2.1/module2.1.5"]
}

In some complex situations, however, you might end up with quite a long list. For example, imagine that you want all modules in your language, 100 or more modules, except for one of them. In cases like this one, you can specify a list of lists, where each list has two items:

  • A type of filter, which is a string, either "include" or exclude.
  • A list of modules to filter.

This way you can specify a secuence of module inclusion and exclusion. For example:

{
    "aff": [["include", ["*"]], ["exclude", ["badmodule1", "badmodule2"]]]
}

Example¶

The following is a real-life example of a language.json file:

{
    "presets": {
        "drag": {
            "default": true,
            "displayName": "DRAG",
            "description": "Vocabulario do dicionario da Real Academia Galega e regras de suxestión de diversas fontes.",
            "aff": ["norma", "rag/gl"],
            "dic": ["norma", "rag/gl"],
            "rep": ["*"]
        },
        "comunidade": {
            "displayName": "Comunidade",
            "description": "Vocabulario e suxestións de diversas fontes. Inclúe vocabulario non presente no dicionario da Real Academia Galega.",
            "aff": ["*"],
            "dic": ["*"],
            "rep": ["*"]
        }
    }
}
